author: obsessedwithstocks
body:
Buying 25 shares would be just a regular market order. I’m referring to buying options/contracts. I’m going to risk $1000 on 2 calls on Salesforce next week.

If the stock rises, 25 shares would make you decent money. But if you were to risk 5K on call options, and the stock price rises, you will make HELLA money. No I’m not a troll. I’m also 22 years old. I’m dead serious about Salesforce. I’d recommend that you do a lot of research this weekend before buying a call... to understand wtf you’re doing. Personally, I’m going to buy a $190 call 2/28.

author: tinyraccoon
body:
My stab on saas:

Both AWS and azure will be good, but I think aws will remain the leader.  I dont think googl or IBM can catch up.  

I think there are too many analytics, cybersecurity,  and payroll softwares.  Some will be consolidated while others will go bust.  

Splk looks solid in the big data analysis niche.

Adbe is strong.

Crm is good but will face increased competition from other paas.

I dont like servicenow.  Singular product and team is catching up quickly with a cheaper product.  

I can see googl focusing more on ai and big data than cloud infrastructure.  It might buy splk.

author: ShipThieves
body: It might be somewhat clarifying to do this with a handful of other meme stocks and maybe a couple of more standard market favorites (e.g. Microsoft, TTD, Salesforce, etc) so we can compare them against each other. Might be a little easier to see whether this just correlates with increased popularity of reddit + WSB, or whether it could potentially be nefarious in nature. Also, we have to keep in mind that the longer the market goes up, the more people pay attention cause of FOMO + ATHs + positive news stories. Plus I'm sure the number of investors has exploded in recent years due to trading being more accessible/cheaper than it ever has been. Just some things to consider.

author: tinyraccoon
body:
Generally, I try to diversify not only in terms of sectors but also in terms of style (e.g. value vs. growth) and exposure (e.g. cyclical vs. secular growth, foreign exposed vs. domestic).  At any given time, certain stocks tend to do well while others not as well, so by diversifying exposures, it is less frequent that the entire portfolio will go down.  

For example, due to the coronavirus and global fears, secular growth and/or more domestic stocks like MSFT, CRM, GD are doing better nowadays.  However, if the coronavirus fears subside, cyclical and more globally exposed stocks like CAT, CVX, SBUX might start coming back and the current leaders might take a breather.

author: PracticalArtist4
body:
> But Im starting to wonder if hard work analysis pays off.

Why? Because somehow doing a 40 page paper researching every single line item on an obscure chemicals company is supposed to entitle you to to incredible returns? 

Hard work does not equate to superior returns. Finding amazing companies that are growing their earnings power equates to superior returns. 

It blows my mind every time I see a value investor lamenting how "easy" it has been for tech investors to make money. Yes buying and holding amazon or apple or salesforce has been an amazing strategy for the last 10 years and its been "easy" vs scouring through the filings and identifying a cigar butt.. no doubt. But the genius has been in identifying that the Amazons, Apple's, Salesforce's of the world have FAR superior business models compared to brick and mortar traditional businesses. 

TL;DR Hard work is important, but it doesn't guarantee returns. Finding great companies and holding on to them guarantees returns.

author: Zer033x
body:
NVDA is on fire lately. Great earnings and lots of analyst upgrades.

TTD will likely beat earnings next week, might make a run to mid 320s before earnings.

PTON is near bottomed out, so probably only up from here til next earnings.

ROKU is pretty low despite a good beat on earnings and will likely rebound to high 130s low 140s in a week or two.

BA is auto buy on calls in the 325-330 range or lower, so much bad news could only push it that low.

Despite TSLA runup it's still a valid play on dips to 800s or lower, a lot of demand still.

MSFT is awaiting Jedi contract decision so is likely range bound between 182-187 until then.

XOP and other fuel/oil type stocks are at lows and consolidating, could be good medium/long term to play a bounce.

Once Coronavirus news dies down AAPL will be in 340s or higher due to a great earnings release that never really got realized in stock price.

WYNN is a valid Coronavirus rebound play.

AMD is a very strong stock right now. It's run up a lot lately but has strong support in mid 50s.

SPCE is a meme stock but can make you rich or wipe you out. Keep bets small and potentially triple your money or more. Strangle could even work with how much it moves.

Cloud stocks and software are actually pretty resilient right now and if Coronavirus news spreads could be considered safe haven. Things like CRM TWLO OKTA MSFT NOW ADBE MDB.

I don't trust LK or its current rebound.

Video game stocks are stable right now, EA and ATVI, but not high risers. Will likely stay range bound or rise slowly until next earnings. Could be good swing trades due to consistency.

DIS continues to drift lower. This isn't anything new. DIS is a boring stock until it isn't, and jumps 20% in a day then starts its long drift lower again.



I think that's all I got for now.

author: jasonlurk
body:
High growth tech names like SHOP, AYX, ZM, DDOG just to pick a few all have high multiples. But names like these have historically had higher multiples than the rest of the market. The question for me is whether these names deserve to have extreme multiples relative to companies that look just like them historically. 

The answer for me is no. These companies trade at 3-5x higher multiples than companies who were consistently growing  +40% annually. I track software names and have been doing so for personal and professional reasons for 20 years. A high growth name like SHOP could consistently get a 8-12x trailing revenue multiple. Today its 30-40x. 

There is no justification for the multiples we are seeing today. You cannot model out a scenario where these companies grow into their multiples and feel good about betting on that business case. I say this because there are only a handful of precedents who have managed to grow at a high rate and generate cash flow over long (5-7years or more) periods of time. 

You cant hold out hope that a big strategic will take them out at these levels because the price point is too dilutive. Plus there is practically been no strategic M&A for these faster growers in the last year or so. I think the best case you find is Salesforce acquiring Tableau. And DATA in that situation had slowed but CRM didn’t pay 30-40x revenue for it either. Another one could be IBM buying Red Hat but then again IBM paid alot for the business but no where near 25x revenue. 

SHOP and others are trading at outrageous multiples but beware these are not sustainable and they leave no room for error.
